1.20.text:
- Hi, thanks for joining
us for The Family Plot:

5.84.text:
Snakes do a great job
controlling pests,

9.74.text:
Also, water-wise gardening
not only saves water,

12.61.text:
but keeps you from having to
go outside as much on hot days.

17.92.text:
The Family Plot: Gardening
in the Mid-South.

- [Voiceover] Production
funding for The Family Plot:

for successful gardening

International Paper Foundation;

62.56.text:
- Welcome to The Family
Plot, I'm Chris Cooper.

64.83.text:
Joining me today
is Andy Williams.

66.40.text:
Andy is the manager at
Lichterman Nature Center,

70.10.text:
Joellen is a TSU Extension
Agent in Tipton County.

75.58.text:
- All right, so, Andy, you
brought something for us to see.

78.18.text:
- I brought a lot to
see, a lot to talk about.

82.05.text:
- When you first talked
about doing today's show,

83.28.text:
you said, "Well, let's
talk about snakes."

85.19.text:
And so I did bring an animal
ambassador, but I wanna talk

88.06.text:
about snake bites, and
why people fear snakes.

91.59.text:
Snakes evoke probably the most
extreme emotional response

94.80.text: of any of our education animals.

96.83.text:
And a lot of it's
hyped on TV, folklore,

100.17.text:
back in the Old
Testament Adam and Eve

103.24.text:
But snakes do a good job of
ridding your garden of pests,

107.27.text:
but there are some issues
with venomous snakes

111.65.text:
Now one thing I do want
to put out a disclaimer,

114.08.text:
the information that we're
gonna talk about this morning

115.75.text:
has to do with snakes
in the Memphis area.

118.02.text:
If you get outside
the Memphis area,

119.55.text:
particularly other parts of
the world, the attributes

122.92.text:
of venomous snakes can be
different in important ways.

127.16.text:
But to put it into context,
about 45,000 people

130.23.text:
in the United States get
bitten by snakes every year,

132.63.text: you know over a huge country.

135.44.text:
Of those, probably six
or seven thousand people

138.57.text:
are bitten by venomous
snakes, and of those,

141.81.text: only five or six people die.

145.38.text:
but still it gives you an
idea of the scale of it.

148.72.text:
When talking to the
students about snakes,

152.09.text:
people, the first thing
the students will say is,

155.62.text:
Well, of course, anything
with a mouth can bite you,

157.56.text:
but you get a show of hands
of how many people in the room

160.16.text:
have been bitten by
little brother or sister,

162.36.text:
you get a big show
of hands, right?

164.83.text:
No one in the room typically
has ever been bitten by a snake

168.64.text:
or knows anyone, but still,
people fear, and rightly so,

175.34.text:
Memphis, as far as
venomous snakes go,

177.44.text: is not too bad of a place to be.

179.28.text:
We have four types
of venomous snakes

180.81.text: that are possible in our area.

184.75.text:
Two of 'em are rattlesnakes,
this is a Timber Rattlesnake,

191.02.text:
But there really aren't
a lot of rattlesnakes

192.49.text:
in the Memphis area, they
tend to be more forest

195.80.text:
and that sort of stuff,
and that's good news,

198.07.text:
because of the snake deaths
in the United States,

202.20.text:
the five or six people
who do die of snake bites,

206.81.text:
Common in our area,
though, are Copperheads

209.48.text:
and Water Moccasins, and
I brought a freeze dried,

212.78.text:
this is an adult Copperhead,
and I brought a mount

216.68.text:
that shows some different
types of snakes,

221.56.text:
Copperheads are probably
the most frequent source

224.99.text:
of snake bites and
that sort of stuff,

226.39.text:
but people rarely
die of their bites.

228.40.text:
Cottonmouths may chase you,
they live near water and such,

231.16.text:
but as far as people gardening
and all that sort of stuff

233.57.text:
in Memphis, provided you
don't have a pond or swamp

236.20.text:
in your backyard, a
Copperhead is probably the one

239.44.text: you're most likely to run into.

242.61.text:
But even though, I'm
getting ready to give you

245.25.text:
some information that if you
can tell this information,

247.55.text:
you're too close, but a couple
tips to tell the difference

252.72.text:
one of the most
characteristic in our area

255.56.text:
have to do with
looking at the heads.

258.13.text:
Venomous snakes have elliptical
pupils, like cat eyes,

261.29.text:
and non-venomous snakes
have round pupils,

266.03.text:
Venomous snakes heads are
arrow-shaped, and the reason

269.14.text:
they're arrow-shaped,
actually their venom glands

273.77.text:
and venom's a modified
form of saliva.

276.78.text:
If you could look under
their tail, you'd see

279.88.text:
under the anal plate, venomous
snakes have a single line

284.32.text:
of scales, whereas non-venomous
have a double line.

288.42.text:
And if you are lucky
enough in my parlance,

291.12.text:
to find a snake shed in
your backyard, you can tell

294.16.text:
if it's venomous or non-venomous
by looking at the tail.

299.53.text:
- And that gives you an
idea of what to look around,

301.10.text:
but if you can tell these
thing, you may be too close.

303.84.text:
I did bring an
animal ambassador,

306.64.text:
this is a Speckled King
Snake, this is the most common

310.44.text:
There's seven sub-species
of king snakes, this is one,

313.88.text: but again, it's the most common.

316.05.text:
They're called
king snakes, one of

317.28.text:
their favorite foods
are other snakes.

319.05.text:
They're said to be immune
to the venom, and they have

321.79.text:
special techniques of
latching on to the head

324.52.text:
of venomous snakes to keep
them from getting bitten.

327.96.text:
But like other snakes, they
are secretive, they hang out

332.07.text:
in the same sort of areas
and they're well adapted

334.03.text:
for hunting, they also
eat lizards, mice,

337.60.text: a wide variety of other things.

340.81.text:
- Oh yeah, all
snakes help us out.

342.58.text:
In fact, one of the things that
attract snakes into the area

345.01.text:
if you have mice and
that sort of stuff,

346.28.text:
they pick up on that and
come in search of food.

352.15.text:
But if you run into
a snake in the wild,

353.92.text:
rather than getting in
close to look at the eyes

356.72.text:
or the tail, your best
bet is to step back slowly

360.09.text:
three feet, and typically,
the snake will scamper away.

364.23.text:
Snakes are attracted to
motion and that sort of stuff,

366.13.text:
but any case, in the wild,
you wanna put some distance

368.67.text:
between yourself and the
snake, however if you do see

375.08.text:
a snake, like I said,
it's common sense,

378.48.text:
Of the people that
get bitten by snakes,

380.28.text:
40 to 50 percent of them
actually picked the snake up.

384.28.text:
- And they're honestly
surprised when they get bit.

387.35.text:
- But unfortunately,
if you do get bitten,

391.73.text:
you wanna take some
certain precautions.

394.69.text:
Even a non-venomous snake
bite, you can get lacerations

397.53.text:
from the teeth, they
have needle-sharp teeth

399.50.text:
that point backwards,
so if you pull,

402.17.text:
you can actually injure
the snake if you pull out,

405.44.text:
but if you get bitten by a
venomous snake, the first thing

408.81.text:
to do is to get
away from the snake.

410.61.text:
Again, that should
be common sense.

414.01.text:
- But if you get bitten by a
snake, thanks to all the hype

416.85.text:
on TV, books, so forth and so
on, people the first symptom

421.32.text:
of snake bite is just
overwhelming fear,
and it's not caused

424.89.text:
by the bite of the
venom, it's caused

426.96.text:
by your over-emotional response
to being bitten by a snake.

430.40.text:
And then if you do
unfortunately, get bitten

433.23.text:
by a venomous snake,
your rapid pulse rate

435.94.text:
and all like that, from gettin'
excited about the situation,

440.54.text:
But you wanna get
away from the snake,

441.88.text:
see if you can identify
it, but the main thing

443.08.text:
is to get away from
it, to elevate the part

447.15.text:
that gets bitten, around
the area of your heart.

450.62.text:
You wanna remove any rings or
watches, because you probably

454.05.text:
will swell up if
it's not a dry bite.

456.69.text:
And by the way, 25 percent
of even venomous snake bites,

459.43.text:
particularly adults, they
don't use all their venom,

462.16.text:
they have a good
amount of control.

464.50.text:
If they're hunting for food,
they just use a little,

466.20.text:
but unfortunately, if
they're being defensive,

467.77.text:
if you step on them or
they think you're going to

470.40.text:
corner them, they
will use more venom.

473.14.text:
But you elevate it,
you wrap it loosely

476.14.text:
and get medical attention
just as quickly as you can.

479.51.text:
One thing, I learned this
in camp and it was fun,

482.98.text:
about this, but we've
been taught over time

485.35.text:
that you're supposed to
put an X on it with razors,

488.32.text:
suck the venom out,
apply a tourniquet,

490.59.text:
and that sort of
stuff, and we now know

492.69.text:
that all that's the
wrong thing to do.

495.60.text:
But again, the most
important thing

497.33.text:
is to seek medical
attention and tell them

500.53.text:
what you know about
the experience,

502.17.text:
and let the trained
professionals do
the rest on that.

504.77.text:
- So sucking out the
venom and that stuff

506.21.text: that we see on TV is not--

507.57.text:
- No, no, but
anything about snakes,

509.38.text:
particularly snake bites
are serious, and should be

511.54.text:
taken seriously, but it's
not a death sentence,

514.51.text:
except for just a handful
of cases that come up.

517.88.text:
- Alright, man, and
we appreciate that
good information.

522.39.text:
- And hopefully we won't be
scared of snakes (laughing)

526.59.text:
- [Chris] There are a
number of gardening events

527.79.text:
going on in the next
couple of weeks.

529.70.text:
Here are just a few
that might interest you.

554.55.text:
And folks, I don't know if
they really wanna go out there

556.39.text:
and water their plants,
so can we help 'em out,

560.09.text:
- Yeah, and something that
they can do right away,

562.10.text:
one of the first things
that you can do if you

564.30.text:
haven't already
done this is mulch.

567.07.text:
Simply putting some mulch
on the ground will help

569.87.text:
retain moisture in the
soil and it will also keep

574.54.text:
the temperature more stable
for the roots of your plants.

577.94.text:
It can also help
when it degrades,

582.78.text:
it will add nutrients
to the soil.

585.69.text:
And of course, it prevents
that crust, because sometimes

588.29.text:
when the water hits the
soil surface, it puts

590.16.text:
a little crust layer on
the soil, and then when

593.13.text:
it rains again, that
layer is so tight

596.00.text:
that it lets water run off
rather than soak in the ground,

598.93.text:
and mulch helps
prevent all of that,

601.10.text: so mulching is a great idea.

603.57.text:
Another thing that you
can do to help yourself

605.91.text:
and your plants is to
water either in the morning

610.08.text:
or in the evening
before the sun sets.

612.38.text:
You've got to let the flowers
and the leaves dry off

617.12.text:
before the sun sets,
because that's gonna set

620.29.text:
a perfect scenario for
diseases to set in,

623.06.text:
so you wanna prevent that,
but watering in the morning

626.13.text:
and watering in the evening
is a nicer time of day,

629.16.text:
it's cooler, morning is the
best if you can do that,

633.10.text:
but you know with people's
hectic schedules and trying

635.27.text:
to get to work, as long as
you water in the evening

637.94.text:
before the sun sets so that
the leaves can dry off,

640.77.text: that's a good time to water.

642.28.text:
Another thing you can do is
plant groups of plants together

646.11.text:
that require the same types
of water requirements.

650.22.text:
And how will you know you've
done that, well, if you have

653.45.text:
a container or an area
that you planted a whole

656.72.text:
different kinds of plants
in there, you water 'em,

659.49.text:
and then some of them
die, well they don't like

662.70.text:
that much water or you
don't water 'em enough

665.13.text:
and some of 'em live, and
some of 'em didn't live

669.10.text:
Well you'll know that
the water requirements

672.24.text:
for that particular plant that
didn't live is not conducive

676.58.text:
to the other plants that
you've planted it with.

680.31.text:
Good examples for some dry
kind of flowers and plants

686.75.text:
that can take drought would
be like your Dusty Millers

690.76.text:
and your Lantanas,
also there's some grass

696.83.text:
it does really well
with dry areas.

700.23.text:
Then of course for larger
trees, you've got your hollies,

704.50.text:
anything with, you gotta
think thick leaved,

707.71.text:
anything that has got
a thick leaf on it

709.18.text:
like your Indian Hawthornes
and your Magnolias

712.35.text:
and your Hollies, those
all can take some drought

716.28.text:
because they have
thicker leaves on them.

720.19.text:
A lot of herbs can do that
too, you think of your sages

723.92.text:
and your oreganos and your
rosemaries and the bay leaf,

730.23.text:
all of those can take
more drought situation

732.73.text:
because they have
larger, thicker leaves.

736.77.text:
Let's see, also, Memphis
area is very humid.

744.08.text:
and I don't like putting water
in the air to water things.

750.38.text:
If you can use soaker hoses,
that would be the best thing

753.35.text:
that you can do, because
it puts water right on

756.42.text:
the root zone where
the plants need it.

759.26.text:
And you will save yourself
money and time by having

762.76.text:
soaker hoses, and just all
you have to do is go out

765.67.text:
and hook up a soaker hose,
and come back in and then

767.57.text:
30 minutes later go out and
check, and maybe give it

770.54.text:
another 30 minutes or
not, and you're done,

773.74.text:
and you don't have to stand
there and water anything.

777.58.text:
So if you can use some
kind of system that puts

780.48.text:
as large of particles of
water as possible out,

785.05.text:
you're not gonna be evaporating
a lot of it in the heat,

787.79.text:
so you're not gonna make
Memphis any more humid

789.72.text:
than it already is, but yes,
and you'll save yourself money

793.93.text:
in the long run because you
won't have to use so much water.

797.86.text:
And now if you have some
time, when you are planting,

804.14.text:
I highly recommend adding
organic matter to the soil

808.27.text:
because soils here in this
area are very small in size,

813.11.text:
and they are very tightly
held together, there's not

816.25.text:
a lot of air and water movement
and space for the roots

820.12.text:
to even grow, so if you amend
the soil, organic matter

825.69.text:
will break that up and give
you larger areas to hold water,

833.67.text:
So you're gonna do a
better job for yourself,

837.07.text:
save yourself some time in
the long run and not use

840.17.text:
as much water if you have
water that stays in the ground

845.14.text:
a lot longer, and organic
matter will help you do that.

848.01.text:
- Yes, I can hear Mr. Jim
Vogus in my head right now,

851.08.text:
"Pour space, that's what
we need, pour space."

856.32.text:
- And organic matter will help
you do that, it sure will.

860.06.text:
- Now let's go back to the
mulchings for a second,

862.40.text:
so do you prefer
one over another.

865.73.text:
- It depends on what it
is, and where it's at.

868.80.text:
I tend to like mulches that
are gonna stay on the ground

871.97.text:
for a lot longer, and
that's like your cypress

875.11.text:
and your cedar mulches,
because you don't have to spend

878.01.text:
more money to add more mulch
to the soil, and that's,

882.18.text:
I usually put those in areas
that I've already finished

884.72.text:
and I'm not gonna be digging
in those areas anymore.

888.29.text:
Another thing, if you've got
slopes, you've gotta watch,

891.52.text:
you don't want something that's
gonna run, so pine needles

895.83.text:
tend to really do well on
slopes, and hold the soil

900.30.text:
and all the plants and
everything so that's,

903.14.text:
I would prefer that, it
depends on the situation

905.20.text:
is what mulch I would
prefer to put on there.

908.27.text:
- I think about the pine
needles and the slopes, okay,

912.75.text:
And you did mention about
using the soaker hoses

916.12.text:
because you don't want that
foliage to be wet, you know

919.19.text:
with the overhead watering which
I see a lot in the evening,

922.39.text:
in my own neighborhood, yeah
that's just prime set up

925.96.text:
for fungal diseases
and things like that,

928.36.text:
so we don't want
people to do that.

929.83.text:
- And if you're really
good, then you'll have put

932.90.text:
the soaker hoses down and
then mulched on top of them,

936.04.text:
so you've got even, and in the
sunlight, it'll look better,

939.27.text:
the sunlight won't degrade
the soaker hose, and they can

941.91.text:
stay in there for years and
years and years and years.

945.34.text:
- And I do like the whole idea
of grouping plants together

949.65.text:
of water requirements, I
think that's pretty smart.

955.29.text:
And they all look good,
there's a lot of plants

957.19.text:
like succulents for example,
very popular right now,

961.76.text:
and they don't take
a whole lot of water,

966.13.text:
- Of course, I have to
throw in, native plants,

967.77.text:
once they're acclimated and
well-established, tend to

970.80.text:
respond favorably to the amount
of water we get in our area.

973.81.text:
- Yes, they do, and they can
take more of our soils, too,

980.65.text:
Alright, Joellen, we appreciate
that information, alright.

987.95.text:
- Alright, so we're
gonna take a good look

989.46.text:
at this watermelon, as you
can see the bottom of it

992.46.text:
has blossom in-rot, and
what that pretty much means

995.39.text:
is that calcium is not
moving throughout this plant.

998.63.text:
And this is also an indicator
of a calcium deficiency,

1002.10.text:
so this is the importance
of doing a soil test.

1004.44.text:
You do a soil test, you
find out how much calcium

1006.21.text:
is in this soil, if you need
to add calcium, please do that,

1009.78.text: but the major problem with this

1012.08.text:
is you need more
moisture consistency.

1014.65.text:
You need a more consistent
watering regime,

1017.25.text:
which is why it's
always good to mulch,

1018.95.text:
because that mulch helps
regulate soil moisture.

1022.09.text:
So either you're giving
it too much water

1023.59.text:
or you're not giving it
enough water, so add mulch

1025.83.text:
and that will help with
your moisture control.

1028.63.text:
You're not going to be
able to correct the problem

1030.20.text:
that you have here now,
but you will be able

1033.77.text:
So again, this is blossom
in-rot, moisture control

1038.57.text:
throughout the
plant as it should.

1045.04.text:
Alright, so here's
our Q and A session,

1046.48.text:
and Andy, you jump in there
and help us out, okay?

1049.32.text:
- Alright, here's our
first viewer email,

1050.75.text:
"With all the rain this
spring, every acorn

1055.12.text:
"My lawn is full of four
or five inch shoots.

1057.46.text:
"I kept my flower beds cleaned
out until I left for town

1060.53.text:
"for about a week, now I can
hardly find my bedding plants.

1063.86.text:
"Am I destined to live
in an urban forest?"

1069.47.text:
"I have huge trees and hundreds
of saplings in my yard.

1074.77.text:
"my leaves were mulched
instead of raked.

1077.01.text:
"What caused all the
tree saplings to grow,

1079.25.text: "and how do I get rid of them?"

1081.25.text:
So the first question
from Miss Jane,

1083.02.text:
and the second question
from Miss Marilyn

1084.78.text:
here in Shelby County, are
kinda related, so urban forest,

1088.19.text:
is she destined to
live in an urban area?

1090.32.text:
- Well, if she let them all
grow, yes, that would be,

1092.36.text:
you know, quite a lot of trees
growing in the same place,

1096.13.text:
but like the trees and the
saplings that are coming

1099.17.text:
in the lawn, you know, just
spray broad leaf weed killer

1102.54.text:
on that, and that should
take care of those.

1107.61.text:
In the beds, well, you
know what, we've just had

1109.74.text:
a really good acorn year this
last year, so I think that's

1113.11.text:
why we're seeing more
acorns coming up in beds,

1117.22.text:
especially if they got
covered up a little bit,

1119.85.text:
just if they got covered a
little bit, through the fall

1123.46.text:
and over winter, and
that's prime time for them

1126.63.text:
to all start germinating and
coming up at the same time.

1129.76.text:
Digging them up, putting some
kind of herbicide on them

1133.17.text:
is your best bet, but
you just have to watch

1135.64.text:
what kind of plants
you're around, just--

1137.60.text:
- Okay, anything you
wanna add to that?

1139.11.text:
- Oh yeah, this is one of my
favorite topics, you know.

1140.61.text:
Actually, believe it or not,
we were talking about this

1143.01.text:
at the dinner table with
my in-laws the other day.

1146.05.text:
- Exactly the same
thing, they have fescue,

1147.51.text:
and they were concerned about
even the broad leaf thing,

1149.75.text:
you know, the hot weather and
fescue are a bad combination.

1152.35.text:
And so the viewers won't
like this solution,

1154.42.text:
but my in-laws' solution
is to spend 15 minutes

1156.66.text:
when they get home each evenin'
pulling up the seedlings.

1161.16.text:
My personal solution
in my woodland garden,

1163.90.text:
out in the dead of winter,
after the acorns drop,

1166.63.text:
and typically it's a
thing to do on a cold day,

1168.70.text:
January, February, and
that sort of stuff,

1170.50.text:
to rake the acorns, you know,
your plants are dormant,

1174.67.text:
you rake 'em onto a hared
surface, and then you can take

1177.34.text:
a broom and dustpan and
actually get rid of 'em.

1180.08.text:
Now I do set 'em aside
for the wild animals

1181.61.text:
and that sort of stuff, but
even when they don't sprout

1184.62.text:
and become nuisance seedlings,
you can, they're like,

1187.32.text:
particularly on the
sidewalks and like that,

1190.36.text:
and you can slip and
they're a safety hazard.

1192.86.text:
But, raking and sweeping
them up, to me, and what,

1195.96.text:
an ounce of prevention
is worth a pound of cure.

1198.03.text:
- [Chris] That's right.
Okay, I can get with that.

1200.33.text:
And there's something else I
do, 'cause I actually have,

1202.17.text:
you know, some of these
acorns that will sprout

1203.77.text:
in my flour beds, if we've
had enough rain, they're easy

1206.37.text:
to pull up, okay,
and that's one thing.

1208.64.text:
And then in my yard, I actually
mow, just mow 'em down,

1213.71.text:
of course, in an
acorn over time,

1216.42.text:
so eventually it peters
out for the most part.

1219.95.text:
So, yeah I either pull 'em
up or I mow 'em in my lawn.

1223.19.text:
- If you snap 'em up,
there's enough energy left

1225.09.text:
in the seedling unless you
do resort to a herbicide

1228.86.text:
or you keep choppin'
you're gradually

1232.10.text:
reducing the energy
store over time.

1233.60.text:
- You're depleting the
carbohydrates, so that works.

1236.60.text:
Alright, so Miss
Jane, Miss Marilyn,

1239.14.text:
Alright, so here's
our next viewer email.

1241.24.text:
"I have several tall Leyland
Cypress that are turning brown

1244.54.text:
"from the inside out,
as in the insides

1247.38.text:
"of all their branches are
turning brown and dropping,

1249.48.text:
"but the outside
leaves are fine so far.

1253.02.text:
"Can I save my Leyland
Cypress, or should I just

1255.86.text:
"cut them down and start over
with something different?"

1263.26.text:
Joellen, I know you chompin'
at the bits to get at this one.

1265.63.text:
- Yeah, well if it's just dying
on the inside, it's probably

1269.57.text:
just 'cause it's getting larger
and there's not enough light

1272.77.text:
to support needles on
the inside of the tree,

1276.21.text:
so there's really
nothing wrong with them.

1278.74.text:
Now he doesn't say whether
he's got a lot of shade

1281.15.text:
or a lot of sun, he doesn't
say if there's sections

1283.25.text:
dying out, because if there
are large sections dying out,

1287.19.text:
that's that Seiridium Canker
that Leyland Cypress get,

1290.22.text: and there's no cure or that.

1292.02.text:
- [Chris] There is no
cure, that's right.

1293.26.text:
- [Joellen] So yes,
if you have that,

1294.76.text:
then you're gonna want to
replace them with something,

1296.76.text:
but if they're just dying from
the inside and the outside

1300.43.text:
looks perfectly fine,
they're just getting large

1302.90.text:
and they're not getting light
inside to produce needles.

1307.14.text:
- And if you let my channel
my inner Carice for a second,

1310.81.text:
you know she would tell you
not to plant a mono-culture

1313.61.text:
of these type of plant
materials, because
Seiridium Canker,

1316.28.text:
as we well know, here in
Shelby County's pretty much

1318.08.text:
taken out the cypress,
the Leyland Cypress.

1321.15.text:
Seiridium Canker is doing
that, of course the canker

1323.36.text:
interferes with water movement
or water flow up the plant,

1327.19.text:
so yeah, if you get
sections that die out,

1330.93.text: it's not coming back from that.

1332.60.text:
Right, so you have to take
out the plant material,

1334.43.text:
but you got some good questions
that we need to ask Mr. Jeff

1339.04.text:
and figure out what
the problem is.

1342.81.text:
- So Mr. Jeff, if you
call the Extension office

1345.24.text:
in Tipton County, in Shelby
County, we'd be more than happy

1347.11.text:
to come out and take a look
at it, see what's goin' on.

1350.05.text:
Alright, so here's
our next viewer email.

1352.55.text:
"My brother in Maryland
has a tremendous problem

1355.49.text:
"with stink bugs, they have
invaded his home inside,

1358.72.text:
"and he has used traps outside,
insecticides, and simply

1362.90.text:
"catching them on tissue and
flushing them down the toilet."

1366.87.text:
Andy, so what can you do
to get rid of stink bugs

1372.61.text: And this is from Roger in Milan.

1374.71.text:
So, he wants to get rid of
stink bugs in the house.

1379.28.text:
- Well go back to the ounce
of prevention, pound of cure.

1382.11.text:
You've gotta seal the ways
they're getting into the house.

1384.48.text:
Typically they come to
the house over winter,

1386.32.text:
they like to go up to attics
and that sort of stuff.

1389.02.text:
Especially with the toilet
tissues, I have no problem

1392.63.text:
with natural killing
things, but they stink,

1395.66.text:
so you're gonna get
that all over you

1400.17.text:
If you have to indoors,
they're weak because they've

1402.30.text:
come into winter,
and particularly in
Maryland, they have

1406.74.text:
a longer winter there,
and so they stay inside,

1408.51.text:
and so they're weak from
not eating for months,

1410.51.text:
but I would recommend if you
can, put a liner in a shop vac,

1414.85.text:
not your house vacuum, but
one you use for utility

1417.75.text:
and put like a shop rag or
something for the insects

1420.92.text:
to attach to, and then
you can suck them up.

1424.49.text:
You're still gonna get some of
the odor, but you can contain

1427.73.text:
it in that, and it wont'
permanently mar your equipment.

1431.73.text:
You can kill them pretty easily,
I said they're pretty weak

1434.80.text:
when they're inside,
but the best thing to do

1437.34.text:
is to keep 'em from
gettin' inside your house.

1439.94.text:
- I would agree
with that. Joellen?

1441.74.text:
- Yeah, that's
what I would think.

1443.38.text:
The other thing I was gonna
say is also, try to keep

1447.85.text:
the shrubbery and
weed population down
around your house,

1452.18.text:
because that attracts
them, they see plants

1455.15.text:
that they can eat,
and then they'll,

1457.16.text:
"Oh, this is a nice,
warm house to go into."

1459.66.text:
So if you can keep the shrubs
trimmed, and the weeds down

1464.30.text:
around the house, that
will help prevent them

1467.10.text:
from attracting to
your house, too.

1470.84.text:
And then again, there are
some exterior controls

1472.97.text:
that you can use, using the
insecticides, they're not

1475.44.text:
as good, again pyrethrum
is for the most part,

1478.38.text:
but sealing cracks and crevices
is what I would recommend.

1481.85.text:
- Obviously if you apply
insecticides successfully, they,

1484.18.text:
if you use safe ones, they're
gonna go away over time,

1487.69.text:
so you forget it about it,
and before you know it,

1491.59.text:
- Alright, Mr. Roger,
so there you have it.

1494.83.text:
Andy, Joellen, we're out of
time, so thanks for being here.

1498.60.text:
- Remember, we love
to hear from you.

and the mailing

Or you can go online to

1605.70.text:
"I have dusted with seven
dust, but they have returned,

And this is from Miss

1615.28.text:
So Andy, they are everywhere,
these Japanese beetles.

1622.49.text:
with few natural predators,
and although I'm fairly

1626.23.text:
averse to using
herbicides and pesticide,

1631.53.text:
- But timing is everything,
you gotta consider

1635.50.text:
the lifecycle, most beetles
spend most of their life

1638.57.text:
as a grub underground,
and during particularly
in the winter

1644.21.text:
or cooler weather, the grubs
go farther down underground,

1645.51.text:
and you can't blast 'em
out with a nuclear bomb.

1651.02.text:
- But, typically the
best time, I believe,

1653.95.text:
to get both the adults and
the grubs near the surface

1657.22.text:
tends to be, isn't
July, thereabouts?

1662.76.text:
dormancy, and they're
apparently the adults will feed

1667.83.text:
during the day, and then
the females go right down

1669.27.text: into the ground to lay the eggs,

and this time of year's when
they're most successful?

- Well, and one thing
we've gotta understand

1678.94.text:
is they give off a

1682.21.text:
attracting more to the

1687.62.text:
collect them, or if you see

1690.69.text:
what you need to do is put
'em in some soapy water,

1693.56.text:
so apparently that will
eliminate the pheromone

1702.70.text:

use those pheromone traps,

1704.97.text:
they're really good about

1707.87.text: - Right, yeah, they say not to.

attract for that reason.

1712.51.text:
But of course, they eat
a lot, it's not just

1715.85.text:
one Japanese beetles, they
invite all of their friends,

1718.38.text:
and then of course, they
eat between the veins.

1720.29.text:
I have roses at
home, and they can

1724.46.text:
But if, you can do that
with the soapy water

1727.99.text:
early in the morning, because,
they're a little slower

1731.03.text:
and sluggish early in the
mornings before it starts

1732.93.text:
to warm up, just knock
'em in the bucket,

1734.97.text:
or a little saucer or

1737.34.text:
and there are some pyrethroid,
to me that's a last result,

1745.98.text:

along with Carbaryl, if

to me that's last result, but

is what I've read
